_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: PAA storage tanks and associated piping

_exec_summary.SummaryText: s an up-to-date emergency action plan.  The plan details the actions plant employees would take in the event of a release of peracetic acid, incidents involving other substances, fires, and health emergencies.  The plan details the means to notify all workers of incidents and actions to be taken, such as site evacuation and headcount; and includes contact information for local emergency response organizations, including the Kingman Fire Department. Evacuation plans are available and evacuation escape plan maps can be found throughout the facility.  The site maintains inventories of emergency equipment and supplies on site.

he accidental release prevention program includes:

	Process Safety Information, which includes:
o	SDS sheets for products containing peracetic acid, 
o	safety information for peracetic acid products 
o	inventory which is an ongoing update of quantities with products containing peracetic acid on hand
o	warehouse layout 
o	design codes and standards utilized in construction and project engineering

	Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)/Risk Assessment, this includes a process hazard analysis for peracetic acid product storage and handling.  The PHA analyzes scenarios that represent deviations from normal operation, the causes and consequences of these deviations, the safeguards in place to prevent or mitigate releases of hazardous materials, a qualitative assessment of the risk of these scenarios (using a risk matrix for scenario severity and likelihood) and the identification of any recommendations to prevent or mitigate risk 

	Standard Operating Procedures which include instructions on handling peracetic acid products

	Training  including training for operators handling peracetic acid products, in addition to emergency response training, and OSHA-required safety training, such as hazard communications, personal protective equipment, and hearing protection.

	Incident Investigations and Procedures  which is a list of all incidents or near miss occurrences, the results of investigation into those incidents, and follow-up documentation of corrective actions 

	Mechanical Integrity/Maintenance program  inspection, testing and preventive maintenance for the equipment and instrumentation utilized in peracetic acid handling

	Compliance Audits  which document the findings and corrective actions from internal and external site audits, including insurance company audits.

Five-year accident history  there have been no accidents in the previous five years that meet the RMP requirements for inclusion in the RMP submittal.

has a vapor pressure greater than 10 mm Hg. Peracetic Acid Process is an RMP covered process. PAA will exceed the 10,000 pound threshold:

2 x 3,000-gallon mixing tanks and one 3,200-gallon storage tank = 9,200 gallons
9,200 gallons x 9.42 lbs/gallon x 23% = 19,932 pounds.

Additionally, warehouse capacity of 300  x 330 gallon totes = 99,000 gallons
99,000 gallons x 9.42 lbs/gallon x 23% = 214,493 pounds.

To be eligible for Program Level 1 there needs to be no public receptors  based on the offsite consequence analysis below there are public receptors. Therefore, the PAA Process is not Level 1.

Any covered process is subject to Program 3 if either the process is covered by OSHA PSM, or the process is in one of ten NAICS codes. 

The process is not covered by PSM, because PAA that is less than 60% is not covered.  

The Process is not covered by one of the following: NAICS Codes: 32211, 32411, 32511, 325181, 325188, 325192, 325199, 325211, 325311, or 32532.	
	
 Since the PPA process is neither Program 1 or 3, it is therefore Program 2. 

Kingman Worst-Case Scenario

The worst-case offsite consequence scenario would be a catastrophic release from the 3,200-gallon PAA storage tank. 3,200 x 9.42 x 0.23 = 6,933 pounds of peracetic acid, released into the 7,838 square foot building. The estimated toxic endpoint is 0.6 miles. The results of the RMP Comp are shown in Figure 1 and the affected area is shown on Figure 2. 

Kingman Alternate-Case Scenario

The alternate-case offsite consequence scenario would be a release from a leak in a 2 diameter pipe (3.14 square inches) from the bottom of the 3,200-gallon PAA storage tank. Releasing 6,933 pounds of peracetic acid over 3.7 minutes into the 7,838 square foot building. The estimated toxic endpoint is 0.2 miles. The results of the RMP Comp are shown in Figure 3 and the affected area is shown on Figure 4. 

Kingman has implemented an accidental release prevention policy to ensure compliance with the EPA RMP regulation.  T

Since 1855, AFCO has been delivering chemical, process, training, equipment, and distribution solutions to leaders in the food, beverage, and hospitality industries that help them operate at the best and highest levels of sanitation, productivity, and profitability. AFCO is a full-service partner throughout all areas of the client facilities and their process management. Working alongside our clients AFCO delivers expertise and hands-on support to help meet sanitation, compliance, and operational needs efficiently and cost-effectively.
The 360,000 square foot Kingman facility serves as a site for the manufacturing, packaging, and distribution of AFCO products. The facility is divided into two sections. Section One is used for manufacturing and distribution of Peracetic Acid (PAA) and is 105,000 square feet. Section Two is used for the distribution of other AFCO cleaning, sanitation, and maintenance products. The Kingman facility became fully operational in early 2022.   

PAA is an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Risk Management Planning (RMP) listed chemical and is produced at the Kingman facility by mixing glacial acetic acid (GAA), hydrogen peroxide, nitric acid, and de-ionized (DI) water from bulk storage tanks located on site, along with the manual addition of other chemicals. The PAA is mixed in two 3,000-gallon mixing tanks. The PAA is pumped from the mixing tank into 330-gallon totes primarily, and in some cases into 55-gallon drums. There is a 3,200-gallon PAA storage tank. The warehouse has the capacity to store 350, 330-gallon totes of PAA.  The Kingman facility will ship products to other AFCO facilities and directly to customers. 

Based on the materials handled, and offsite consequence analysis, the Kingman facility is characterized as a Program 2 facility. 

RMP Program Level Determination

Peracetic Acid (PAA) [Ethaneperoxoic Acid] (CAS 79-21-0) is listed in 40 CFR 68.130  List of Substances. With a threshold of 10,000 pounds. Peracetic Acid
